titlestmt.titleproper: National Association of Composers, U.S.A. records
Finding Aid for the National Association of Composers, U.S.A. records PASC-M.0080
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by UCLA Library Special Collections staff, Caroline Cub√©.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-08-12 15:37:02 -0700.

did.unittitle: National Association of Composers, U.S.A. records

physdesc.extent: (6 document boxes, 14 flat boxes, and 1 oversize flat box)

did.abstract: This collection contains the records of the National Association of Composers, USA (NACUSA) and those of its preceding body, the National Association of American Composers and Conductors (NAACC). Records include minutes, correspondence, treasurer's reports, chapter information, concert programs and announcements, clippings, and other material; and cover the transition from the NAACC to NACUSA. Also included are musical scores contributed by approximately 110 of its member composers.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Audio materials in this collection are restricted and require production of listening copies. To access materials, notify the reference desk in advance of your visit.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], National Association of Composers, U.S.A. Records (Collection PASC-M 80). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

acqinfo.head: Provenance/Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of California State University, Dominguez Hills, 1988.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: The National Association of American Composers and Conductors (NAACC) was a non-profit and volunteer- run organization founded in 1933, in New York, by Henry K. Hadley. The NAACC was one of the longest standing organizations in the United States devoted to the promotion and performance of American concert hall music. The organization maintained chapters in Los Angeles, Philadelphia, Colorado, Indiana, and the District of Columbia, and included its members in annual concerts, given to the public free of charge. The NAACC was led by Henry Hadley until his death in 1937, after which his wife, Inez Barbour Hadley, took over and ran the association until her death in 1971. After a period of inactivity, UCLA professor and conductor John Vincent took on the leadership of the NAACC in 1975 and changed the association's name to National Association of Composers, USA (NACUSA) and moved the headquarters from New York City to Los Angeles. By 2015, NACUSA was presenting several chamber concerts each year featuring music by its members, publishing a newsletter, and holding a national contest for young composers aged 18-30. Over the course of its existence, the organization has included many well-known American composers as members.
Source: National Association of American Composers and Conductors Papers, JPB 03-15

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the records of the National Association of Composers, USA (NACUSA) and those of its preceding body, the National Association of American Composers and Conductors (NAACC). Records include meeting minutes, financial reports, chapter records, newsletters, correspondence, concert programs and calendars, competition and other event announcements, clippings, scrapbooks, and notes belonging to its recording secretary. A large part of the collection contains musical scores by approximately 110 member composers, submitted for performances and competitions, and collected by the organization.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
The collection has been arranged in the following series:
Series 1. Scores
Subseries 1.1. Numbered scores
Subseries 1.2. Unnumbered scores
Series 2. Organizational records.

p.extref: John Vincent Collection (Collection PASC-M 31). Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
National Association of American Composers and Conductors Papers, JPB 03-15. Music Division, The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

controlaccess.subject: Vocal music -- Scores.
Music -- Societies, etc.
controlaccess.corpname: National Association for American Composers and Conductors

did.unittitle: Series 1. Scores

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains scores that were submitted to NAACC/ NACUSA by member composers for inclusion in various competitions and performances. Unnumbered scores have been separated from scores that were numbered by the organization, presumably as an attempt to archive them. No index exists for these numbered scores. There is overlap in composers between numbered and unnumbered scores.

Series 2. Organizational materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains the organizational materials of both the NAACC and NACUSA. Included are membership materials and rosters, meeting minutes, chapter information, financial reports, newsletters, and correspondence. Also included are clippings, concert programs and calendars, and event announcements and invitations. Much of this material was maintained by recording secretary Naomi Reynolds, to whom a large part of the correspondence is addressed, and to whom member composers sent concert programs, clippings, and news of their accomplishments, for inclusion in Reynolds' "Prospect and Retrospect" column in the NACUSA newsletter, Composer/USA. Reynolds' notes and planners are also included here. This series also includes five volumes of scrapbooks containing ephemera from the organization's various activities.

Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Much of this correspondence is addressed to recording secretary Naomi Reynolds, to whom member composers sent concert programs, clippings, and news of their accomplishments, for inclusion in Reynolds' "Prospect and Retrospect" column in the NACUSA newsletter, Composer/USA. Also included are correspondence between other members, including organization presidents Ernest Gold and John Vincent.
